Participants.evidence: 910 patients undergoing isolated total arterial coronary artery bypass grafting with internal thoracic arteries (ITAs) at our institution, between January 2017 and February 2020.

Intervention.evidence: TTFM was assessed in 430 patients (TTFM group). They were compared with 480 patients without TTFM assessment (no TTFM group).

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to evaluate the impact of transit-time flow measurement (TTFM) on early postoperative outcomes in total arterial coronary revascularization.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary end point was the occurrence of in-hospital major cardiac adverse events (MACE).

Number_Randomised.evidence: 910 patients undergoing isolated total arterial coronary artery bypass grafting with internal thoracic arteries (ITAs) at our institution, between January 2017 and February 2020.

Result_Outcome.evidence: TTFM was protective against MACE occurrence (odds ratios 0.46, 95% confidence interval 0.23–0.85, P = 0.016).

Harms.evidence: Six (1.4%) patients in the TTFM group versus no patient in the no TTFM group underwent intraoperative graft revision because of unsatisfying flow values ( P = 0.011).
